headline: AI Has Learned to Create Fake News Stories
summary: Researchers warn about the risks of computer-generated articles—and release tools that ferret out fakes.

headline: Typhoon Hagibis Slams Japan, Kills Dozens
summary: One of Japan’s worst typhoons in decades brought record-breaking rainfall to broad swaths of the country, killing more than two dozen people and causing breaches in river levees that submerged low-lying areas.

headline: Democrats Push Warren for Plan to Pay for Medicare for All

headline: Legal Expert Looks Set to Become Tunisia’s New President

headline: Democrats Seek to Keep Ohio a Battleground
summary: Ohio, a quintessential presidential battleground state, is flashing warning signs to Democrats that it is becoming more Republican and might already be out of reach.

headline: The China Trade Truce

headline: Make Dishwashers That Clean Again

headline: Poland’s Ruling Nationalists Look Narrowly Poised to Return to Power for Another Four Years
summary: The conservative Law and Justice party appeared set to continue in government, though it may have to form a coalition with a far-right Confederation party, per exit polls from a general election that saw the highest turnout since 1989.

headline: Cat-Litter Rivals Pounce on New Shipping Strategies

headline: Typhoon Hagibis Drenches  Japan
summary: A powerful typhoon that is forecast to be the worst to hit Japan in six decades reached greater Tokyo. The storm brought heavy rainfall in wide areas of Japan all day ahead of its landfall Saturday evening and continued to batter the capital.

headline: Impeachment, Secret or Not, Roils the House

headline: Arrests May Drop but Minor Crimes Are Not Dropping

summary: The complexity of the Irish border issue defeated former Prime Minister Theresa May and is testing her successor, Boris Johnson. That complexity is due to the EU’s unique nature.

summary: Intensive Brexit negotiations between the European Union and the U.K. will continue on Monday, with diplomats warning that a weekend of talks had produced no breakthrough.

headline: Cuomo Says $900 Million Bridge Sped Up Traffic. Drivers May Disagree.

headline: Wegmaniacs Count the Days to Brooklyn Store Opening

headline: Move Over Brexit, a New Feud Is Riveting the U.K.

headline: Should Consumers Be Able to Sell Their Own Personal Data?

headline: Her Superb Swimming Didn’t Stop With Pregnancy
summary: A swimmer used to going the distance made it around Manhattan and across the Catalina Channel while expecting with guidance from her doctors.

summary: Arkansas’ experience in implementing work requirements for Medicaid recipients—a program halted by a federal judge—illustrates the potential pitfalls for the growing number of states pursuing their own measures.

headline: Don’t Ask Me to Do Office Housework!

headline: Iran’s Expanded Missile Arsenal Tests Mideast Defenses

headline: Sears Hasn’t Fared Better After Bankruptcy

headline: The Military Offers Women Pay Equity and Opportunity, but Few Still Make Top Ranks
summary: Though the armed services tout themselves as a meritocracy, for women the promise remains elusive.

headline: Hunter Biden to Resign From Board of Chinese Private-Equity Firm
summary: Hunter Biden, son of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, said that he wouldn’t work for any foreign-owned companies or serve on their boards if his father is elected president.

headline: Coal Bankruptcies Pile Up as Utilities Embrace Gas, Renewables
summary: More than half a dozen large U.S. coal companies have filed for bankruptcy in the past year, a signal that the one-time king of American energy is fading as it faces competition from cheap natural gas and renewable-energy sources.
